body: @sdedic where is the second link actually supposed to point at?

This was obviously also brought up recently in https://lists.apache.org/thread/dhlwp3wkglfk9265g362olj2b0dphqoq

I'm curious too why the second link has tokens in it?  Is this a mistake in the template in use, or a sign that templating isn't correctly set up at the point it's triggering?
Confirming that CMD-click (Mac) does work on the first link.
Feedback incorporated, 3 days from approval; merging.
Prerequisite PR #3668 merged, so this is ready.
Just random failures from ServerTest / ProjectViewTest. Merging.

> I am not fan of removing API only because it is no longer used by us.

While I mostly agree with this (I do think deprecated for removal has a place), this seems somewhat different?  We're not removing because we no longer use it, but because we have to actively put in workarounds to keep it - well, bring it back.  By that point, in the very unlikely scenario someone needs this, surely _they_ can do the wrapping themselves?

Thanks for your PR, but why not deliver this as a plugin?

The code has multiple license headers, and it is unclear what the provenance of that code is.  It has both (c) Oracle (GPL/CDDL) and (c) HCL (Apache) headers!

If the reason for not making this a plugin aligns with the addition of the friend dependency, then we probably need to discuss opening up the relevant API.

In current state, sorry -1 from me.
planning to merge this PR this weekend. Speak up if there are more change requests.

> Thanks for this patch! I will test this in my next NetBeans build, in a day or two.

@eirikbakke build still running? ;)
Which build system?  And please try with 13.  I wonder if it's the same as https://lists.apache.org/thread/0jhgnn72w7lhcrnjmjv167lctf42qxd2 ?
I am pretty sure CVS is no longer supported

Also now tested on the FlatLAF Dark and Windows LAF. Looks good.

Except one thing: The left-hand text margin is wrong, as shown in the screenshot below. It should ideally line up with the margin of the splash image. (FlatLAF on Windows, 150% HiDPI scaling.) Perhaps check the right-hand margin as well; it may have the same problem (but it may not be visible due to the specific word breaking shown here).

![Margin](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/886243/156388192-e8b24a7d-8032-4f6e-8812-a73960af7882.png)

Another issue, which I guess was mentioned earlier. When there are long lines in the bottom panel, we end up having both horizontal scrollbars and text wrapping. Shouldn't it be just one or the other? In the example below, why is there no text wrapping after "User directory:"?

![Wrap](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/886243/156392567-0799435f-bfd9-41f4-8c12-dd98ff614c20.png)

@eirikbakke I take a look at the margin. It is all set to default, this does also not happen under normal scaling

Regarding the text wrapping. Its html, not sure if i can influence this - I will turn it off if I find something. (edit: `white-space: nowrap;` seems to do the job)

Seems like some archetypes have been commented out:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/5a9c949e8e4e2820109de064f4c2b501dcb49242/enterprise/maven.j2ee/src/org/netbeans/modules/maven/j2ee/ui/wizard/archetype/J2eeArchetypeFactory.java#L148-L149
The commit is https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/3e7e6fe67a0e03f66ec8d86e470042af29494556 in #1298
Is there a reason why those archetypes were commented out @juneau001 ?
As there is no CVS module in NetBeans, this must be an external module. If that is the case, this is not supported.

The error description can't be followed and does not describe an actionable problem. Please provide detailed steps to reproduce, a description of the behavior you observe and a description what you would expect.

Looks good, but as I expected, they're failing RAT tests. The files (or file extension and/or folder) need adding in to the "no degree of creativity" section of the RAT exclusions - https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/nbbuild/rat-exclusions.txt#L56

changed it so that the lower panel won't wrap text anymore. 

Looking at your screenshot again, it appears as if the window is actually slightly larger than it should be, since the image is centered, it isn't on the same line as the start of the text. Without the scaling the image defines the size of the window, and everything is aligned properly I suppose. But you should see the same effect with the old version of the window, right?
If nobody opposes, this will be merged by next weekend.

**UI log** ...

* attached .ZIP file:  [UI-log.xml.zip](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/8174167/UI-log.xml.zip)

Hi, I have a very naive question. I only see that for css we use antlr 3.x and the current antlr is 4.x. I'm not aware how many grammar we have in codebase. But would it be an idea to migrate to last ?
Without a good argument I think it would be no benefit. Rewriting the grammar just poses chances to break the code.

@ebarboni @matthiasblaesing  AFAIK Antlr4 exposes the AST through the visitor pattern (or through events), i.e., you don't have it in memory. The migration Antlr3 to Antlr4 is not straightforward. You'll have to build the AST yourself (see, https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29971097/how-to-create-ast-with-antlr4 for instance).
Nice! And I agree, looks good to me.

thanks for the quick reviews Brad & Martin. I looked through it (again) here on gh and couldn't find any issues + I did some manual testing with a fresh build.

Everything is green -> going to merge it soon before it causes conflicts.

We feel if this plugin is getting distributed along with the Netbeans product, it will help BOTH VersionVault and ClearCase user, which means this plugin will work for both VersionVault and ClearCase.
It looks ClearCase plugin was obosolete some time ago and we took(from - https://github.com/emilianbold/netbeans-releases/tree/master/clearcase) that as a base and we upgraded and rebranded it to VersionVault. 

We have forked a copy of netbeans sources https://github.com/apache/netbeans/ and included upgraded netbeans-versionvault/clearcase plugin.
Also included the copyright statements for the files we have modified/upgraded, rest are same as from old ClearCase plugin  https://github.com/emilianbold/netbeans-releases/tree/master/clearcase. 

You have mentioned to distribute as a plugin, which means we need to upload the binaries to a netbeans market place from which our customer can pick it up? if yes, can you please share the location or process for that?
@eirikbakke if this PR doesn't make it worse for high dpi / UI scaling modes i would like to merge this anyway. Someone else interested in this would have to debug it. I am running 1080p screens.
@mbien Fine with me.

Hi @GaneshrajS30 , as Neil has detected this code is not compatible with the Apache License.

You can create your own plugin instead, following the instructions here https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NETBEANS/How+to+get+plugin+on+Plugin+Portal+Update+Center
btw, the template does not list "netbeans 13" as available NetBeans version
Please provide a minimal, reproduceable sample of the problem, else it won't be possible to help you.

The generated project structure looks strange on the verge of broken. When I use a maven project and generate code (for example from annotations), it is common, that the generated code is placed in:

`target/generated-sources/<name_of_generator_or_custom_set>/<packages>`

In the case of your sample, a whole maven project is generated in `target/generated-sources/<name_of_generator_or_custom_set>` (there is even a pom.xml there). This is irritating and IMHO broken. The code generator for maven should do just that: generate code, not whole projects. Generating projects might be helpful for POM projects, but even then the placement looks broken.

I found an option to change the source base, but I'm missing an option to surpress the wrongly created pom.xml. I did not look into the code, but I assume, that NetBeans detects the pom.xml and assumes a new projects starts at that point. Again IMHO a valid assumption.

@tigerinus , you want to read openapi-generator-maven-plugin documentation at https://github.com/OpenAPITools/openapi-generator/blob/master/modules/openapi-generator-maven-plugin/README.md 

Specifically the generated-sources output directory
```
<output>${project.build.directory}/generated-sources</output>
```
And the files to generate.
@neilcsmith-net added it to the ignore list, everything is green -> merging
Also it is painfully slow to add a library folder. I think it has to do with parsing the directories or something. (I'm a newb)

> > The code generator for maven should do just that: generate code, not whole projects.

>  @matthiasblaesing  - I'm afraid I can't do anything to the openapi generator project since I don't own it.

The generator generates a broken structure, so why should NetBeans try to make sense from the broken structure? Given, that you can already change the source directory, it should be doable to add a "don't generate project file" option to the generator.

I created a PR with changes, that at least allow parsing of the structures. It is most probably not perfect, but at least allows working the files in a sane way. Please see the referenced PR for the changes themselves. If you can't build from source, here is a test build:

[NetBeans-dev-dev-18f9648d4000a2f0f025e23cf728f16812f9774c-release.zip](https://doppel-helix.eu/NetBeans-dev-dev-18f9648d4000a2f0f025e23cf728f16812f9774c-release.zip)

It would be good if you could test it.

> The generator generates a broken structure, so why should NetBeans try to make sense from the broken structure? Given, that you can already change the source directory, it should be doable to add a "don't generate project file" option to the generator.

Got it. I guess I will have to stay with VSCode + Eclipse JDT extension for now.

Thanks guys!
Also related: https://github.com/apache/netbeans-jenkins-lib/pull/56

[curent-notarize-log.json.txt](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/8189273/curent-notarize-log.json.txt)
Current log from the notarization service
@tigerinus this is one interpretation. I think I outlined what would be required to get a sane result from the generator.

> and all the passwords crash after a minor or major update

what does this mean, what is the exception?

> btw, the template does not list "netbeans 13" as available NetBeans version

thanks. update pending https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/3703
no exception, no errors... after the update, i re-open netbeans, open my project, and when i open the project properties, and open remote connections, all the password are disappeared !!
ok, so nothing breaks, the passwords of the connections are just not imported to the next release? You have to enter them again?
exactly ! but i have more than 10 passwords... and i don't to re-enter each time the software update !!!

this is going to be difficult to resolve if there is no reproducer provided.

(Issues like this can be influenced by so many factors that they will be usually closed after a while due to inactivity)

> Let's get this in. Sorry, forgot about this with everything else yesterday - had put it on my list of release tasks. Thanks!

Neil, you are doing an excellent job. Its all good.

@Ojambo thank you for the detailed report.

I personally prefer to use the shell for most git tasks so I never noticed. I put NB 14 milestone on this issue since i think we should try to fix this if there is time/interest.
Just installed 13 without a problem on the latest OpenJDK 17 by Azul, downloaded from foojay.io/download. (On Windows, i.e., same binary as above.)
My suspicion is, that the identifier for the password entries contains the version number. People on a dev build will never notice, because it does not change there. I'll have a look at that.
@matthiasblaesing does the snap distribution use the same config migration mechanism as regular upgrades? (never used it)

The error looks real (only glancing at the screenshot). I suppose the installer might parse the wrong properties and makes assumptions of the java version number, that don't hold anymore.

Someone would need have a look at the place in the installer where the error message is generated and retry with an Oracle JDK.

I assume, that not many people use Oracle JDKs. At my employers place after the binary license stunt Oracle pulled for JDKs, usage of them is treated with scepticism and so Alternatives from Azul, Amazon, Adoptium or even Microsoft are more popular.
Duplicate of #3684

Most companies I know use the Oracle JDK. I'm working in the enterprise environment and a lot of companies have already existing contracts with Oracle for many years or even decades. In these companies, this is more a management decision than technically or legally based.

Anyhow, it would be great to take a look at the installer. It should work with Oracle JDK, even if it is not a very popular JDK in the open-source world.

Thanks for taking care!
\\_()_/ I was just reporting the bug like the IDE instructed me to.

If the project can be built successfully using `mvn` then an IDE should be able to load the project. I believe `mvn` simply choose to ignore any extra `pom.xml` in the sub directory, so does Eclipse JDT. Technically speaking from perspective of a compiler at root project level this structure is not broken. 

But I understand the rationale behind that Netbeans treats it as broken structure and refuses to build. That's completely fine to me.
Can you see if you can reproduce your issue with a different JDK?
After the weekend, when I have access to the Windows machine again.

The problem seems related to a wrong detection of java install in my system (standard ubuntu linux with open jdk 17)

After reinstallation and manual selection of the JDK to use everything seems fine.

So maybe that's a bug in the installer?
Are you interested in more details?

@matthiasblaesing : yes i think it is true. i just have discover that it has created a new folder ( for the new version ) in my home dir, subdir netbeans, like this :
/home/snap/netbeans/52 ( old version )
/home/snap/netbeans/58 ( new version )
/home/snap/netbeans/current ( link to 58 )
dir-52 and dir-58 have same subdirs...

what can i do to get back my passwords ?
I fixed this. I'll try to create a PR.
With NB13 in Windows with the above example scanner code from @mbien , it worked for me.

I created a pull request and here is a test build:

https://doppel-helix.eu/NetBeans-dev-dev-ff00b6542e7a8c5e8fa39a0d8f0df663b7061e0f-release.zip

I tested ecdsa and ed25519 keys on linux. Support for SSH Agents was only tested with an rsa key on Windows and Linux (PAgent and SSHAgent). The ssh bundle was marked to depend on:

- JNA (Integration of PAgent)
- JUnixsocket (Integration of SSHAgent)
- Bouncy Castle (Support for more exotic Keys on not so new JDKs)

The updated SSH library integrates support for agent integration, so the dedicated NetBeans modules was removed.

@sdedic you might want to have a look at this. I remember, that you asked to be included in changes, that might touch vscode. This is the case here, as vscode had a reference to the removed ssh agent integration module.

For the IDE this should work, as all relevant dependency modules (jna, jna-platform, bouncy castle and junixsocket) are either in the IDE or the Platform cluster, it might be necessary to adjust the vscode build to include them too.

This looks reasonable, so something must be different at your end. Could you please:

a) check the JDK again - is it maybe a prerelease version, this might mess up the detection code (and would make this less of an issue, given, that the previous/next released version is always less than 6 months in the future)
b) run the installer with verbose logging, review the log for security sensitive information and put it here (or a subset of it)

That explains it. For a time while NetBeans was transitioning from Oracle to the Apache Foundation the old binary servers were still availabile. bits.netbeans.org was one of them. At some point in time Oracle cut of the servers and thus the old binaries are not available anymore.

You might be able to rebuild the module from old sources, but Apache NetBeans does not offer that module. If it should be revived:

a) it needs to be checked if the old CVS code was donated
b) if it was donated, it needs to be cleaned up and restored into working state
c) if it was not donated, it needs to be reimplemented

If it was not donated, the plugin could be build externally and distributed under GPLv2/CDDL (as the original one). This all needs someone to do it.
See #3477 for a discussion about it

@AlohaWebSolutions NetBeans has multiple keyring implementations and it depends on the runtime enviroment which is used. At this time I would expect the libsecret based implementation, but that is speculation.

Please run NetBeans with the following command line argument: `-J-Dorg.netbeans.modules.keyring.level=FINE`. This enabled logging from the keyring provider and it will create a logging output like this:

```
FINE [org.netbeans.modules.keyring]: Using provider: org.netbeans.modules.keyring.gnome.libsecret.GnomeLibSecretProvider@63edd129
```

In the sample the `GnomeLibSecretProvider` is used. Please post the output here.
@mbien I assume, that the snap distribution also makes the native keyrings available, thus I would expect behavior of ZIP distribution and snap to be identical.
